extendedIngredients.name: onion
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 small onion, peeled and thinly sliced

extendedIngredients.name: shrimp
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1/2 pound medium shrimp, peeled and minced

recipes.title: Ginisang Ampalaya at Hipon (Bitter Gourd and Shrimp Stir-fry)

winePairing.pairingText: Fish works really well with Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. The Vampire Pinot Grigio Wine with a 4.5 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 18 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Vampire Pinot Grigio Wine
productMatches.description: This dry, zestful combination is reminiscent of ripe pears and roses

recipes.instructions: Cut ampalaya lengthwise and scrape off seeds and white pith. Slice thinly and place in a bowl, covered in cold water until needed.In a wide skillet, heat oil over medium heat. Add onions and garlic and cook, stirring regularly, until tender and aromatic. Add in tomatoes and cook until softened, regularly mashing with back of spoon.Add fish sauce and cook for about 1 minute. Add shrimp and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until shrimp starts to change color.Add water and bring to a boil. Drain ampalaya from water, add to pan and gently toss to combine. Cook for about 2 to 3 minutes or until tender yet crisp.In a thin stream, add eggs and gently stir to distribute. Continue to cook for about 1 minute or until eggs have set. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot.

steps.step: Cut ampalaya lengthwise and scrape off seeds and white pith. Slice thinly and place in a bowl, covered in cold water until needed.In a wide skillet, heat oil over medium heat.
Add onions and garlic and cook, stirring regularly, until tender and aromatic.
Add in tomatoes and cook until softened, regularly mashing with back of spoon.
Add fish sauce and cook for about 1 minute.
Add shrimp and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until shrimp starts to change color.
Add water and bring to a boil.

Drain ampalaya from water, add to pan and gently toss to combine. Cook for about 2 to 3 minutes or until tender yet crisp.In a thin stream, add eggs and gently stir to distribute. Continue to cook for about 1 minute or until eggs have set. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
